content.title: The Core Rule
content.text: If the formatting carries meaning that matters beyond appearance, use a semantic element. If the formatting is purely decorative with no meaning to communicate, use CSS on a span instead of a presentational HTML element.

examples.title: All Text Formatting Elements in a Technical Documentation Page
examples.description: This example uses every major text formatting element in a realistic technical documentation context. Each element is chosen for its semantic meaning, not its visual output. Comments explain why each element was selected over its visual-only alternative.
examples.code_snippet:
Node.js fs Module Reference

Warning: all synchronous fs methods block the event loop. Use them only in startup scripts, never inside request handlers in Express or Fastify applications.

fs.readFile

This method reads the entire file into memory before calling the callback. For large files, prefer fs.createReadStream instead. 

// Asynchronous (non-blocking) - preferred
fs.readFile('/data/config.json', 'utf8', (err, data) => {
  if (err) throw err;
  console.log(data);
});

// Synchronous (blocking) - use only at startup
const data = fs.readFileSync('/data/config.json', 'utf8');

Method Signature

fs.readFile(path, options, callback)

The options object accepts an encoding string and a flag string. If options is a string, it is treated as the encoding value directly.

Changelog

The bufferSize option was deprecated in v14.0.0 and removed in v16.0.0. Use highWaterMark instead.

Terminal Output

Run node read.js in your terminal. On success you will see:

{ database: 'postgres', port: 5432, ssl: true }

If the file is missing, Node prints: Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, open '/data/config.json'

Performance Notes

For files larger than 10 MB, the memory overhead of readFile becomes significant. The highlighted threshold applies to the default Node.js heap configuration.

Version Support

Behaviour described here applies to Node.js v18 LTS and above. Older versions may differ. Always check the official Node.js documentation for the version you are running.

A dark code block shows pre and code together with preserved indentation. The method signature shows var in purple italics for parameter names alongside inline code. The changelog shows del in red strikethrough and ins in green underline. The terminal section shows kbd for user input and samp in a green monospace badge for program output. The 10 MB threshold is marked in yellow. The version note appears in small grey fine print.

when_to_use.point: When the formatted text carries meaning that matters to screen readers or search engines
When displaying code, keyboard input, or program output in documentation or tutorials
When marking changed content with del and ins in changelogs, diffs, or corrections

when_to_avoid.point: Avoid strong and em for visual styling when the text has no actual importance or stress
Avoid pre for indentation tricks in prose; it is only for content where whitespace is meaningful
Avoid nesting block elements like pre inside p as p only accepts inline content

what_it_solves.1: Visual styling alone conveys no meaning to screen readers or search engine crawlers.

what_it_solves.2: Without code and pre, source code loses its indentation and structure when rendered in a browser.

what_it_solves.3: del and ins communicate document history to tools and readers without removing the original text.

conceptual_understanding.model: Semantic text elements are like annotation layers on a manuscript. The text is the manuscript. The semantic tags are coloured stickers a librarian places on specific words: red for warnings, blue for technical terms, yellow for highlighted passages. A sighted reader sees the stickers. A cataloguing system also reads them to index the document. CSS-only styling is invisible ink: it affects appearance but leaves no sticker for any system to read.

The strong versus b distinction mirrors the difference between a red STOP sign and red decorative text on a restaurant menu. Both are red and bold. Only one communicates urgency. A screen reader navigating by importance will find the STOP sign but skip the menu decoration. strong is the stop sign. b is the menu text.

pre is a time capsule for whitespace. When HTML is parsed, all consecutive spaces and line breaks normally collapse into one space. pre opts out of that rule. Every space, every indented line, every blank line is preserved exactly as written. This is the only correct tool for source code, terminal output, and any content where the position of whitespace carries meaning.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using strong and em for decorative bold and italic text: When every third sentence is wrapped in strong for visual emphasis, the word loses its meaning. Screen readers and search engines that weight strongly-marked text now receive noise instead of signal. Reserve strong for genuine warnings or critical information and em for words where stress actually changes the sentence meaning.

Using pre for layout indentation in prose: The pre element is for content where whitespace carries meaning, not for creating visual indentation in paragraphs. Text inside pre is rendered in monospace with every space and line break preserved, which breaks the natural line-wrapping of body text and produces unexpectedly wide or narrow blocks.

Using code for all monospace styling regardless of content: code has a specific semantic meaning: computer code, variable names, file paths, or commands. Using it purely to get monospace styling on non-code content misleads screen readers and search engines about the nature of the text. Use a span with a CSS font-family for monospace styling on non-code content.

bonus_tips.tip: Combine kbd elements for keyboard shortcuts by wrapping each key separately: <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>S</kbd>. This lets you style each key as a separate badge via CSS and gives screen readers individual key names to announce. The plus sign between them is plain text, not inside kbd, because the plus is punctuation connecting the keys rather than a key itself.

Use del and ins together with the datetime attribute to record when a change happened: <del datetime='2024-01-10'>old text</del> <ins datetime='2024-01-15'>new text</ins>. The datetime attribute is machine-readable and follows the same ISO 8601 format as the time element. Tools that process document history can use this to build a revision timeline.

subtopics.title: Strong and Emphasis Elements
subtopics.description: Strong signals importance or urgency and em signals spoken stress that changes a sentence meaning.

content.title: When to Use b and i Instead
content.text: Use b for stylistically bold text that carries no importance: product names, keywords in a summary, bold text in a UI. Use i for alternate voice, foreign words, technical terms, or titles of works. Neither b nor i communicates importance or stress to assistive tools.

examples.title: strong vs b and em vs i with Meaning Demonstration
examples.description: This example places strong, b, em, and i side by side in identical-looking sentences to show that the visual output is the same but the semantic meaning differs. It also demonstrates how placing em on different words in the same sentence produces different meanings, which is the core purpose of the element.
examples.code_snippet:
strong vs b and em vs i

strong vs b: both look bold, only one carries meaning

strong: high importance (screen readers may signal this)

Do not delete this file. Removing it will break the application on next startup.

Meaning: this specific instruction is critically important.

b: stylistically bold, no importance (screen readers ignore)

This guide covers React, Vue, and Svelte.

Meaning: product names are highlighted for readability, not urgency. b is correct here. strong would be wrong and misleading.

em vs i: both look italic, only one shifts sentence meaning

em: stress emphasis (changes which word carries the sentence weight)

I never said she stole the money.

Meaning: someone else said it, not me.

I never said she stole the money.

Meaning: someone stole it, but not her specifically.

I never said she stole the money.

Meaning: she may have taken something, but not the money.

i: alternate voice or non-emphasis italic (no stress change)

The algorithm is known as binary search in computer science.

The novel The Pragmatic Programmer is essential reading.

In French, a general store is called a épicerie.

Meaning: alternate voice or different register, no spoken stress implied.

Nesting strong and em for combined importance and stress

You must restart the server after every configuration change.

strong wraps the must (important). strong wraps em wraps every (both important and stressed). Nesting is valid and additive.
examples.output: Page renders all comparisons visually identical: strong and b both appear bold, em and i both appear italic. The semantic difference is invisible to sighted users but significant to screen readers. The three em sentences demonstrate how shifting emphasis to different words ('I', 'she', 'the money') changes the implied meaning of the same sentence. The i examples show technical term, book title, and foreign word usage. The nesting example shows strong and em combined.

conceptual_understanding.model: strong and em are like a highlighter and a sticky note on a printed page. The highlighter marks text that matters most (strong). The sticky note marks a word that a reader would stress aloud when reading it (em). b and i are the same colours but just decorative pen strokes: they look the same but carry no instruction to any reader, human or machine.

The em element models spoken language. In speech, stressing a different word in a sentence changes its meaning. 'I never said she stole it' has seven different meanings depending on which word you stress. em encodes that stress into HTML so that text-to-speech tools and language processors can read the sentence with the correct inflection the author intended.

bonus_tips.tip: When using i for a foreign word or technical term in a different language, always add a lang attribute to the element: épicerie. This tells screen readers to switch pronunciation rules for that word, producing correct speech output. Without lang, the reader applies the document language rules and mispronounces the foreign term.

examples.output: Page renders a search results section where every occurrence of 'Node.js' is highlighted in yellow by mark. The pricing section shows two plans, each followed by small grey fine print with billing details. The changelog shows version numbers with timestamps, ins entries in green underline for additions, and del entries in red strikethrough for removals. The footer shows small copyright text. The del and ins entries both carry datetime attributes for machine-readable change records.

conceptual_understanding.model: mark is a highlighter pen used by a student after the fact, not by the original author. The author wrote the text. The student marks the parts relevant to what they are currently studying. On a search results page, the search engine is the student: it highlights where the query appears in existing content. mark is not for decorative highlighting or general emphasis.

del and ins together create a two-colour tracked-changes view like the one in a word processor. Red strikethrough shows what was removed. Green underline shows what was added. The datetime attribute is the timestamp in the document margin. A tool reading the HTML can reconstruct the history of every change without needing a separate version control system.

bonus_tips.tip: When using JavaScript to highlight search terms in rendered HTML, create mark elements programmatically rather than using innerHTML with a regex replace. Split the text node at the match position, wrap the matched range in a createElement('mark'), and insert it. This avoids XSS risk from injecting raw HTML and keeps the DOM structure valid even when the search term contains special characters.

examples.title: Scientific Notation and Code Documentation Patterns
examples.description: This example shows sub and sup in realistic scientific and mathematical contexts, then demonstrates the four code-related elements together in a documentation pattern. The pre plus code combination is the industry standard for displaying multiline code blocks that preserve indentation.
examples.code_snippet:
Chemistry and Code Reference

Subscript: sub

Water is H2O. Carbon dioxide is CO2. Glucose is C6H12O6. Sulfuric acid is H2SO4.

The boiling point of water at sea level is 100 degrees Celsius.[1] The melting point of iron is 1538 degrees Celsius.[2]

Superscript: sup

Einstein's mass-energy equivalence: E = mc2

Avogadro's number: 6.022 × 1023 mol−1

The 1st place award went to the 3rd entry in the 21st annual competition.

Inline Code: code

Call Array.isArray(value) to check whether value is an array. It returns true or false. Do not use typeof for this check because typeof [] returns "object", not "array".

Code Block: pre + code

The standard pattern for code blocks is pre wrapping code. pre preserves whitespace. code adds semantic meaning. 

function fibonacci(n) {
  if (n <= 1) return n;
  return fibonacci(n - 1) + fibonacci(n - 2);
}

console.log(fibonacci(10)); // 55

Keyboard Input and Program Output: kbd and samp

To run the script, type node fibonacci.js and press Enter.

If the function is correct, you will see: 55

To save a file in VS Code, press Ctrl+S on Windows or Cmd+S on macOS.

[1] National Institute of Standards and Technology, 2023.

[2] CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 104th edition.
examples.output: Page renders chemical formulas with correctly lowered subscript numbers for H2O, CO2, glucose, and sulfuric acid. Footnote reference numbers appear as raised superscript links. The Einstein equation shows mc squared with a raised 2. Avogadro's number shows the exponent and negative-one superscripts. Ordinal suffixes st, rd, and st are raised. Inline code appears in a light monospace badge. The multiline Fibonacci code block renders in a dark container with preserved indentation. The kbd entries appear as key badges, samp shows the output in a green badge, and the keyboard shortcut separates each key into its own kbd element.

conceptual_understanding.model: pre is like a photograph of text. Normal HTML prose is typeset text where the browser decides where line breaks go and how to handle spaces. pre is a photograph: every space, tab, and newline is captured and reproduced exactly as it appeared. This is the only way to display source code or terminal output without rewriting it to remove all meaningful whitespace.

The code element is a semantic label, not a visual style. Wrapping text in code tells every tool reading the page: this is a computer instruction, not a word in natural language. A syntax highlighter reads code elements to know what to colour. A search engine reads them to understand that a term is a programming concept. A screen reader may switch to a different reading voice for code content.

bonus_tips.tip: Always start the content of a pre block on the same line as the opening pre tag: <pre><code>first line of code. Any newline between <pre> and <code>, or between <code> and the first line of content, becomes a visible blank line at the top of the rendered code block. This is one of the most common causes of unexpected extra whitespace in documentation code blocks.
